Context:
Program Name: Web Development – Front-End Design
Code: G418
Credential: Ontario College Graduate Certificate
Duration: 1 year (3 semesters)
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: 7,050.00
International Tuition: 22,485.00
Centre: Arts, Design & Information Technology
School: Design
Location: Waterfront Campus
Program Overview: The one-year Web Development – Front-End Design graduate certificate program focuses on human-centered design to build apps and interfaces that meet industry standards. Students will learn to translate concepts into visual and functional interfaces, websites, applications, and systems. The program covers five pillars: accessible UI design, intuitive UX design, industry workflow and problem solving skills, full-stack application architecture, and front-end development. Effective communication with stakeholders is emphasized in this program as it is critical in the digital economy.

Semester Availability (for 2024-2025):
- Fall: Open for both domestic and international students.
- Winter: Not Available for international students, open for domestic students.
- Spring: Not Available for all students.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Web Development – Front-End Design Program (Postgraduate) G418 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Web Development – Front-End Design program at the college offers training in developing custom front-end interactive prototypes and solutions using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Students learn to integrate the latest libraries and frameworks for improved efficiency and employability. The curriculum covers mastering the development workflow including testing, debugging, documentation, bundling, and deployment. Students apply UI/UX design principles and knowledge from all levels of the design and development stack.

In their third semester, students participate in a Work-Integrated Learning placement or a Work Integrated Project with an industry sponsor. The program offers career opportunities as software engineers and designers, interactive media developers, computer programmers, web designers, or developers.

Required courses for Semesters 1, 2, and 3 include Applied Interface Design, Applied Interface Development, User Interface Design and Technique, Prototyping and Experience Design, Libraries, Tools and Workflow, Front-End Application Architecture, Data Design and Development, Industry Employment and Portfolio, Front-End Frameworks, and either a Front-End Design Field Placement or Work Integrated Project.

Program learning outcomes include determining and documenting web computing project requirements based on stakeholder needs, preparing and presenting proposals and business plans for web applications that satisfy client requirements, and designing, modeling, implementing, and optimizing accessible web solutions to meet client requirements and constraints.

Context:
The International Fees and Related Costs page can be found on the website for more information. This program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet OSAP eligibility criteria. The admission requirements include an Ontario College Diploma, advanced diploma, degree or equivalent in computer science/studies, web programming, interaction design or related fields, or demonstrated work experience in design or computer development. Qualified applicants will be invited to complete a questionnaire electronically and may also be invited for an interview. Applicants with international transcripts who do not provide English proficiency test results must test at the college level in the George Brown College English assessment to be considered for admission. International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.

Contact information:
- School of Design: Phone: 416-415-5000, ext. 3129, Email: game@georgebrown.ca
- Contact Centre: 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559), long distance 1-800-265-2002
- International Contact Us page for recruitment representatives specializing by country of origin.

The program is located at the Waterfront Campus, 3 Lower Jarvis St., Toronto, Ontario, Canada. The School of Design resides in a new 103,000-square-foot facility in the Daniels Waterfront – City of the Arts.
